docs.lead_paragraph: SHE had no birth certificate, no death certificate. But there was, ever so briefly, a human being. All that was left, after nine months of pregnancy, were memories. A fluttering in the belly, an elbow or a foot kicking to the side. Hopes and dreams for a life that ended almost before it began. Two years ago, Eileen Myers of New Hyde Park checked into the hospital for a scheduled delivery. The doctor couldn't detect a heartbeat on the baby.

headline.main: A Place to Mourn and Share 'the Silent Loss'

docs.abstract: Ground is broken at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY, for Babies Memorial Garden, dedicated to bereaved parents whose children have died in miscarriages, stillbirth or childbirth; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the centerpieces of my four years at the Federal Communications Commission was the fight to require every television station to broadcast at least three hours per week of children's educational programming. We won that fight, but now the question is: What to broadcast? Here's my modest proposal. The show is called ''Like, Duh.'' It's ''To Sir, With Love'' meets ''The Magic School Bus.'' The male lead is the head of an emergency education team (reference: ''Charlie's Angels'') that jets around the world to address school crises -- illiteracy, teen-age pregnancy, achievement pressure, etc. -- in different countries. The exploration of how different cultures cope with these issues produces homilies that are strikingly applicable to every culture, proving that ''it's a small world after all'' (reference: Disney/ABC picks this up for synergy).
docs.abstract: Former Federal Communications Commission Chmn Reed E Hundt article proposes children's educational comedy television show; photo (M)
docs.snippet: One of the centerpieces of my four years at the Federal Communications Commission was the fight to require every television station to broadcast at least three hours per week of children's educational programming. We won that fight, but now the...

docs.lead_paragraph: BETTE MIDLER's up-and-down recording career has always been about juggling personas to create a portrait of an entertainer (and woman) of many (often contradictory) parts. And ''Bathhouse Betty,'' her first album for Warner Brothers after more than two decades on Atlantic, is arguably her most multifaceted collection since her 1972 debut recording, ''The Divine Miss M.'' Many of Ms. Midler's continuing characters are here: the blowzy aspiring art singer (''Song of Bernadette''), the post-disco diva (''I'm Beautiful''), the wistfully sentimental Everywoman (''That's How Love Moves''), the Hawaiian hula girl (''Ukulele Lady''), the jazz nostalgist (''I'm Hip''), the original rock-and-roll mama (''One Monkey Don't Stop No Show'') and the brash, defiant smut queen (''Big Socks''). Several of those characters could be bunched under the umbrella of the Divine Miss M, Ms. Midler's campy stage persona who has always suggested a funny, precociously talented little girl playing subversive games of dress-up.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews new recording by singer Bette Midler; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This should be a time of triumph for the conservative, overwhelmingly pro-Republican members of the Christian Coalition. The Democratic, baby-boomer President they have long considered a moral disgrace now faces talk of his impeachment. And yet, in the hallways and during coffee breaks at the three-day Christian Coalition convention here, many delegates said they were despondent about opinion polls showing that most Americans do not share the conviction that President Clinton should resign or be impeached.

headline.main: Christian Coalition Moans Lack of Anger at Clinton
headline.kicker: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE CONSERVATIVES

docs.abstract: Christian Coalition members at convention in Washington bemoan American public's lack of anger at Pres Clinton for his sexual transgressions, and public's refusal to share their conviction that he should be impeached; founders Pat Robertson and Ralph Reed have long issued dire warnings of moral collapse, and point to Clinton scandal as ultimate evidence; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the second time in two years, the Senate today failed to override President Clinton's veto of a ban on a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call partial birth. The vote was 64 to 36, three shy of the two-thirds needed to override. While the debate, the graphic charts, the anecdotal stories and the vote itself were all familiar, the stark mathematics of the November elections loomed large over the Senate.

headline.main: Veto Sustained On Bill to Ban Some Abortions

docs.abstract: Senate, 64-36, falls three votes shy of overriding Pres Clinton's veto of ban on late-term abortion procedure opponents call partial birth; vote focuses attention on drives to unseat Democratic Sens Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois, Barbara Boxer of California and Patty Murray of Washington, abortion rights supporters (M)
docs.snippet: For the second time in two years, the Senate today failed to override President Clinton's veto of a ban on a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call partial birth. The vote was 64 to 36, three shy of the two-thirds needed to override.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman's right to abortion faces a critical test today in the Senate. The House has already voted to override President Clinton's principled veto last year of the latest Congressional attempt to ban so-called partial birth abortions. A Senate vote scheduled for this morning will determine whether this professedly narrow but actually far-reaching assault on abortion rights becomes the law of the land. The latest head counts suggest that Mr. Clinton's veto will stand. But for Americans concerned about government intrusion into women's private medical decisions, this is a moment for nervousness. Two years ago, an effort to rally the required two-thirds of the chamber to override Mr. Clinton's veto of a similar bill fell short by just three votes -- and that was before Mr. Clinton's Monica Lewinsky troubles and the Christian right's expensive lobbying campaign aimed at senators deemed susceptible to pre-election pressure. The Republican leadership, content to let the Christian Coalition's political strategy drive the Senate's schedule, has timed today's vote to coincide with the group's ''Road to Victory'' conference in Washington D.C.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Congress should not override Pres Clinton's veto of late-term abortion procedure known as intact dilation and extraction; warns bill's vague terms could be interpreted to ban safest and most common abortion procedures as well

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking unilateral action while Congress squabbles over legislation, President Clinton will announce new consumer protections on Thursday for more than 15 million Medicaid patients in health maintenance organizations. The new rules range from a requirement that H.M.O.'s allow women to have direct access to obstetricians and gynecologists, without getting a referral or prior authorization, to a guarantee that health plans will pay for emergency services whenever a ''prudent lay person'' would consider them necessary.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, acting while Congress squabbles over legislation, plans to announce new consumer protections for over 15 million Medicaid patience in health maintenance organizations; rules range from requirement that HMO's allow women direct access to obstetricians and gynecologists, without referral or prior authorization, to requirement that plans pay for emergency services that would be deemed necessary by 'prudent lay person;' Senate Republicans, led by Sen Trent Lott, use series of parliamentary maneuvers to block consideration of patients' rights bill proposed by Sen Tom Daschle (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ELECTRIC cables, television monitors, lighting and sound paraphernalia crowded the front hallway of the two-story saltbox house. Gingerly stepping over the wires, I crossed the foyer -- and the family home of my imagination came alive. I spotted the dining room through an archway: a faux-Tiffany lamp hung above an antique table of dark luminous wood, surrounded by six red-velvet Louis XIII chairs. Made to order in Paris by James Ivory and Ismail Merchant for their film ''A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries,'' these were replicas of the originals I grew up with. Real ones would have been too expensive to buy and then ship all the way to the United States, as my parents had done in real life.
docs.abstract: Kaylie Jones Close to Home column on interior decor of her childhood home in Paris that inspired set designs for A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries, new movie by Ismail Merchant and James Ivory; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The flier mailed out this summer to scores of parents may have been anonymous, but it did not mince words. ''Parents of teen-age girls,'' it said, ''what are you going to do if your daughter comes homes pregnant and says, 'If the principal can get pregnant without getting married, why can't I?' ''

headline.main: Principal's Pregnancy: Sex Education; Baby First, Then Marriage, But a Rural Area Is Able to Adjust

docs.abstract: Article discusses how rural community of Hillsdale, NY, is able to adapt to elementary school principal Donna Rich teaching moral values while being unwed mother; Rich had baby in June 1997 and married baby's father in May 1998; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE the nation remains focused on the sex scandal in the White House, the American public is ignoring what could be an even more serious sexual scandal -- the young ages at which boys and girls now engage in sexual intercourse, often risking pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases, including infection with the virus that causes AIDS. Millions of American children are at risk of having unsafe sex, and it is critical that they learn, first, how to resist pressures to have sexual intercourse at such young ages and, second, how to protect themselves from unwanted consequences if and when they decide to go all the way.

headline.main: Teen-Agers and Sex: Younger and More at Risk

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on concern about teen-age boys and girls engaging in sexual intercourse, often risking pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS; findings of New Zealand study quoted (M)
